title: 111_s3632
content: The Act titled "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Enforcement and Prevention Act of 2010" enhances criminal penalties to combat fraud in these programs. The Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Enforcement and Prevention Act of 2010 increases penalties for fraud, including raising fines to $50,000 and imprisonment for up to 10 years for certain offenses. Additionally, a new subsection is added to address illegal distribution of beneficiary identification or billing privileges. The Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Enforcement and Prevention Act of 2010 increases penalties for fraud, including fines up to $50,000 and imprisonment for up to 10 years. A new subsection addresses illegal distribution of beneficiary identification or billing privileges, with penalties of up to three years in prison or fines equal to the monetary loss to the government. The amendments apply to acts committed after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. ENHANCED CIVIL AUTHORITIES TO COMBAT MEDICARE AND MEDICAID FRAUD. Section 1128A(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include new paragraphs related to conspiring to commit violations and knowingly making false records or statements in relation to Federal health care programs. The text discusses amendments to the Social Security Act regarding access to claims and payment data, as well as the implementation of mechanisms for sharing information about suspected fraud in Federal health care programs. Additionally, it mentions a Beneficiary Verification Pilot Program to be initiated by the Secretary of Health and Human Services within a year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will implement a 5-year pilot program called the Beneficiary Verification Pilot Program to verify claims for Medicare reimbursement by directly contacting beneficiaries for verification. The Secretary will provide reports for the third, fourth, and fifth years of the program. The Beneficiary Verification Pilot Program aims to reduce waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicare.
